prompt: Facts: Raj Bala (deceased) married Bhagirath (Respondent 1/Accused 1) on May 19, 1988.; Manphool (Respondent 2/Accused 2) is the father-in-law, and Anguri (Respondent 3/Accused 3) is the mother-in-law of the deceased.; Allegations surfaced soon after marriage regarding demands for dowry (scooter, television) by the accused.; The deceased allegedly faced harassment and cruelty due to non-fulfillment of these demands.; A 'panchayat' was reportedly convened sometime before the incident to address the dowry demands, but the date is not specified.; The deceased, Raj Bala, died due to burn injuries sustained at her matrimonial home on June 10, 1990 (within 7 years of marriage).; The father of the deceased (PW-3 Dharam Singh) lodged the First Information Report (FIR), alleging dowry harassment leading to death.; The defense claimed the death was accidental, occurring while the deceased was preparing tea on a stove.; The Trial Court acquitted all three accused, disbelieving the prosecution witnesses regarding dowry demands and cruelty, and finding the defense version of an accidental fire plausible.; The State of Haryana appealed the acquittal to the High Court.; The High Court reversed the Trial Court's judgment, convicted all three accused under Section 304B IPC, and sentenced them to 7 years of rigorous imprisonment. The High Court believed the prosecution witnesses, found the defense version unreliable, and invoked the presumption under Section 113B of the Indian Evidence Act.; The accused (Bhagirath, Manphool, Anguri) appealed the High Court's conviction to the Supreme Court. | IPC: Section 304B (Dowry Death), Section 498A (Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty - Contextually relevant, though conviction was under 304B), Section 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention - Implied basis for convicting all three accused), Section 113B, Indian Evidence Act (Presumption as to dowry death - Critically discussed)
